name: Tristan Zajonc
bio:
Cofounder/CEO at @Continual_AI.  AI, data, startups, economics. 
Formerly @Cloudera, @SensePlatform.

activity.text:
RT @moinnadeem: This is an important plot from the LLaMa 2 paper. It directly outlines the pre-training hours for the model!

Costs below,‚Ä¶

Llama 2 is remarkably simple. The https://t.co/bT4ugOWehj is 288 lines of Python and the entire repository is <1000 lines.
https://t.co/ifSkPdRcVX

This is huge: Llama-v2 is open source, with a license that authorizes commercial use!

This is going to change the landscape of the LLM market.
Llama-v2 is available on Microsoft Azure and will be available on AWS, Hugging Face and other providers

Pretrained and fine-tuned‚Ä¶
@ylecun Thanks for this awesome contribution to AI.

activity.text: Are there promising contenders to replace vector search for context augmentation?  Injecting chunks into the context feels rather rudimentary honestly.
Technology can help humanity make the world cleaner, healthier, and more connected.  The future will be beautiful if we care enough to try.

quoted.text: do you feel it too? the absence of any optimism for the future? it‚Äôs completely gone from the cultural zeitgeist. such a stark contrast compared to the early 00s. or is it just me getting old and jaded and looking at the past through a nostalgia filter?

activity.text: I'm chatting next week about Production LLMOps with @willpienaar, @changhiskhan, and @Dan_Jeffries1.  It should be a lively discussion with diverse perspectives.  https://t.co/z7V3ZbMfYQ
Really looking forward to the new Google.  Or if not Google, https://t.co/LvEPUynbaY or https://t.co/q82E3bIoQj.   They are going to be awesome.

If the next version of GPT is a leap in performance as GPT-4 was I think fine tuning becomes a thing of the past

Current GPT-4 can go up to 32k context length, what would it mean if the next version did 64k or higher?

Your vertical domain specific model would be one prompt away

@abacaj Being able to tune in a more continuous space is critical to build many experiences where we don‚Äôt know what to prompt but have various forms of feedback.  Fine tuning the entire model is likely not necessary but moving beyond text seems like an obvious win for many applications.

replyTo.text:

There's a chance that LoRA finetunes work so well that it dramatically alters the finetuning vs. retrieval + few-shot prompting power dynamic in favor of the former for many applications.

PEFT (Parameter Efficient Finetuning, LoRA included) are emerging techniques that make it‚Ä¶

quoted.text:
LlamaAcademy: a factory that teaches LLaMA's how write API code. ChatGPT Plugins, but no manifest file is needed -- it just reads the API docs like a human would!

For example, here is a finetuned model that learned how to talk to Notion by reading its API docs: https://t.co/DPJQaUH3u5

activity.text: @karpathy There's a huge need for this to build compelling applications that improve over time.  It's very hard to create a proper data engine with just prompting.

activity.text:
I played with @AnthropicAI assistant (AA) and compared it to @OpenAI ChatGPT
 
TLDR: both are similar but AA is
+ Harder to jailbreak
+ Tries to be more helpful
+ Follows closer what we ask for
+ ~Better for writing in English
- Worst for code
- Worst in French
- Longer resp.
üßµ https://t.co/4lWv4fL69S
@yanndubs @AnthropicAI Wow, imagine how frustrating Google would be if it was aligned this way. https://t.co/3dMsIxv9on

replyTo.text:
**Jailbreaking**
AA is much harder to jailbreak
 
Eg below I easily jailbreak ChatGPT to tell me how to make a Molotov cocktail. AA is harder but breaks after 3rd attempt

Below I also tried to change the constitution of AA but it won‚Äôt let me. Impressive @AnthropicAI!

4/8 https://t.co/yRRaPu08zz

activity.text: Larry Wasserman's "All of Statistics" is arguably one of the best introductions to math stats out there, but do not sleep on his "All of Nonparametric Statistics"! Really good too. It covers a ton: ecdfs, density estimation, nonparametric regression, resampling, and wavelets.
@vsbuffalo Great books!  I wish more books were written like these.

replyTo.text: Larry Wasserman's "All of Statistics" is arguably one of the best introductions to math stats out there, but do not sleep on his "All of Nonparametric Statistics"! Really good too. It covers a ton: ecdfs, density estimation, nonparametric regression, resampling, and wavelets.

I don't do a lot of angel investing even though I'd like to. I'm naturally very skeptical and not a "dice-thrower." In the interest of helping other founders, here's my feedback to someone on a pitch. It's the kind of feedback I would want. https://t.co/zL3yLWZ40d

@esammer I'm actually not a fan of this type of feedback honestly.  The best feedback should help solve the problem.  That could be encouraging a new direction or just stating your best guess solution to some of your open questions. Founders need encouragement.

@tristanzajonc @mim_djo When the parser looks up where to find a table, it first checks for existing DuckDB tables. If none are found, it checks Python (or iPython) local variables of a Pandas / Arrow DF type! Since Pandas uses Numpy, those are C Arrays and DuckDB just reads them! Does that help at all?

activity.text:
‚ÄúAI infra/platform for swe/data/ops teams‚Äù seems to be the area where there are a ton of new (well-funded) companies being founded.

The idea being ML/AI is going to be a core feature of *any* product going forward.

Alas, it has no trendy name like ‚Äúweb3‚Äù to ratchet up the hype.

Surprised there‚Äôs no definitive OSS platform/toolkit for this as yet.

If ML/AL is poised to become integral to any product, then the software infra components on which it is going to be built is headed toward commodity status (as it‚Äôs unlikely it‚Äôll be the key differentiator).

There‚Äôs a lot of those today.

Orchestration, compute (geo, graph), runtimes, serialization, and viz all come to mind.

And like all of ML.

activity.text: Jinja templates are a code smell. Serialized data formats (XML, JSON, YAML) are a terrible user interface and should not be written by human hands. Generate them with code instead.
@alexkyllo https://t.co/BgLZ0BhQ7O is an effort like this. But I think it will be hard to convert SQL lovers because python DSL adds a lot of baggage too.

replyTo.text: @tristanzajonc Good question, something I would love to see is a Python package providing data warehousing domain abstractions on top of SQLAlchemy.

activity.text: Is YAML really the best we can do for declarative feature definitions in ML?

@josh_wills @DarcyShen @changhiskhan @continual_ai The options on the market today are: 1) Inline SQL in YAML, 2) Inline Python in SQL, 3) Inline SQL in Python.  Malloy looks interesting but doesn't seem geared to this problem.  Is there something else out there?  Or is this just a plea for something to get built?

replyTo.text: @tristanzajonc @DarcyShen @changhiskhan @continual_ai I mean, inlining SQL into a YAML file isn‚Äôt good, right? That‚Äôs not what we are defending?

activity.text: What's a good definition when developers talk about "declarative"? I've been thinking in my head it means "define the end state, not the steps to get there", which to me is orthogonal to whether it's described in config or code. Is that right?

@bernhardsson Declarative to me means what you say: define what you want, not how to get there.  e.g. Terraform, Pulumi, SQL.  It's also ok for there to be layers.  Pulumi providers define methods imperatively but are used declaratively.

replyTo.text: What's a good definition when developers talk about "declarative"? I've been thinking in my head it means "define the end state, not the steps to get there", which to me is orthogonal to whether it's described in config or code. Is that right?

activity.text: One thing Kafka Connect got üíØ% right is the composability of sources and sinks (as opposed to "atomic" end-to-end flows). This brings a great freedom of optionality, allowing to add further sinks down the road. A fully OSS tiered storage impl will take this to the next level.
@gunnarmorling You mean tiered storage for the Kafka topic or equivalent, so you can cheaply and easily keep the full changelog around for future consumers?

replyTo.text: One thing Kafka Connect got üíØ% right is the composability of sources and sinks (as opposed to "atomic" end-to-end flows). This brings a great freedom of optionality, allowing to add further sinks down the road. A fully OSS tiered storage impl will take this to the next level.

activity.text: Are tasks and flows really the right abstraction for data ops?  If I remove some data asset (e.g. a table in Snowflake), who is responsible for deleting it?

@josh_wills @teej_m @matsonj @JoshGhalgh @_kulte Definitely the way today, but it gives me the heebie-jeebies.  Why do I need to 1) hack around dbt macros to cleanup renamed tables, 2) figure out some similar process in Airflow for ML, and 3) introduce Terraform just to get a robust analytics-as-code workflow.

replyTo.text: @teej_m @tristanzajonc @matsonj @JoshGhalgh @_kulte ^^ is the way

activity.text: Here comes the "Very Modern Data Stack" according to  @DSJayatillake.  Great outline of a vision for Ruby Labs' future data stack.   https://t.co/fdruuCZSBa. https://t.co/MJMwl7uHVm
I'd probably also put @dagsterio, @PrefectIO, or @MetaflowOSS over @ApacheAirflow for orchestration if we're going to call this a very modern data stack.

replyTo.text: I could see quality/monitoring (@Bigeyedata, @montecarlodata, @datafoldcom), data catalog (@Stemma_ai, @MetaphorData, @SecodaHQ), metrics (@transformio) and Reverse ETL (@HightouchData, @getcensus).

activity.text: @matsonj @JoshGhalgh @_kulte Nice.  It does illustrate the general problem though.  It gets even more acute when the line between infra, policies, and assets isn't clean. For instance, what's the best way to manage warehouses/users/roles in Snowflake.

replyTo.text: @JoshGhalgh @tristanzajonc @_kulte If you also include that macro in your ‚Äòdbt run‚Äô it will drop the tables/views etc - ie with a pre hook.

activity.text: @tristanzajonc What do you mean deleting it? If you remove it from Snowflake it‚Äôs already deleted, right? I know you mean something else though üòä

replyTo.text: Are tasks and flows really the right abstraction for data ops?  If I remove some data asset (e.g. a table in Snowflake), who is responsible for deleting it?

activity.text: @_kulte I probably should have said, "if I remove some task that generates a data asset (e.g. table), who is responsible for deleting the asset."  The point is that infrastructure-as-code operates via reconciliation, whereas data engineering today operates on tasks and flows.

replyTo.text: @tristanzajonc What do you mean deleting it? If you remove it from Snowflake it‚Äôs already deleted, right? I know you mean something else though üòä

activity.text: RT @continual_ai: Grab some popcorn and join this Friday afternoon debate with Continual's Head of Field Engineering and Gustaf from @coile‚Ä¶
AI is increasing centered on data and the input/output spec, not the model architecture.  Great thread by @karpathy.

quoted.text: The distinguishing features now mostly include 1) the data, and 2) the Input/Output spec that maps your problem into and out of a sequence of vectors, and sometimes 3) the type of positional encoder and problem-specific structured sparsity pattern in the attention mask.

activity.text: Back in like 2011 I wrote a blog post (sadly lost forever) about how "data science" was a terrible name, how it didn't express what we did, how it didn't really mean anything, would only confuse people, etc. Now a full decade later it's still true but I'm completely ok with it.
@emilieschario @tayloramurphy @seanjtaylor @coalesceconf On point!

activity.text: I wrote a blog post about how I think the cloud service stack will change in the next 5-10 years: https://t.co/yg2uENSPWy

@bernhardsson @josh_wills @Tailscale Yeah, I was asking if this ends up as vendor managing the VPC and billing for compute/storage (Snowflake) or running in customer VPC (Databricks).  Trend seems to be vendor managed VPC but Vectorized and PlanetScale recently added customer VPC options.

replyTo.text: @josh_wills @tristanzajonc @Tailscale I'm not a networking expert but it's interesting how a lot of the software providers on top use VPC peering so that you can run them as if they are in your own VPC

Ensuring data quality can‚Äôt just be monitoring.  It needs to be coupled with change management. @getdbt tests and @datafoldcom diffs get this right.
Big Complexity is the next challenge after Big Data.  @schrockn
When will we bring things engineers think about all the time to the average professional's workflow? I'm thinking: version control, abstraction / DRY, repeatability, etc. üßµ

@sarahmk125 I can't think of a product that does this well.  If somebody got it right, I think a lot of new disruptive products would copy it.   FWIW, we're trying at @continual_ai by supporting environments (dev, prod) and making everything a declarative configuration change in UI or code.

replyTo.text: 4/ Not everyone should code, but everyone would benefit from coding principles. What am I missing here? Is anyone doing this already in the space? Who disagrees?

activity.text: ML/AI is drowning in complexity.  The status quo of K8s + bespoke models + pipeline jungles + experiment trackers + deployment platforms + monitoring platforms imposes tremendous costs.  The ecosystem needs a deep rethink. Here's why.

@BradPorter_ I should qualify that I'm talking AI consumers not AI vendors here.   Obviously building 1 and 2 will require tons of data, compute and expertise.  I'm also fine with declarative data-first approaches if in-house data is really needed to fine tune.

replyTo.text: @tristanzajonc All three you listed are extraordinarily data intensive.  The production AI systems that are winning are those who have better data, have done more to curate and understand that data, and have figured out how to exploit that data advantage.

activity.text: @tristanzajonc @JagersbergKnut Have you tried to use @knime  https://t.co/eTkDpo3Lp0

activity.text: @iced_soy_latte It will happen in stages. OpenAI style APIs are already starting to completely change the game.  We are in the first inning but the next 5 years will see an explosion in few shot APIs. Zero MLOps infra or team is just too compelling to ignore if it works.

replyTo.text: @tristanzajonc Is it really inevitable? Just because humans can do it doesn't mean it will be easy to develop algorithms that will perform well on as many tasks with few shot learning

activity.text: @kylewadegrove I think you get 10x if you think of the full operational lifecycle.  Personalization and forecasting are use cases with high operation burden today but can made trivial with right dsl.  Data intensive vision is harder but will be data first workflow long term.
The startups I'm watching that promise a 10X+ simplification include @OpenAI, @CohereAI, @SnorkelAI, and, of course my biased favorite, @continual_ai.  But we need many more!

replyTo.text: Finally, the traditional MLOps stack will persist in pockets as the escape hatch. But better tools will bring at most a 2X simplification here.  Over time even these use cases will shift to higher level abstractions that reduce complexity and empower everybody to do more faster.
